title: Equatorial Guinea - Conflict Data
org: Armed Conflict Location & Event Data Project (ACLED)

bites.title: Map of locations
bite: On 7 August 2020, former workers of the Manso Express SL Company demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Labour in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte) to demand the payment of their dismissal allocations and the real reasons for their dismissal. The police forces intervened to disperse them, and arrested at least one. [size=no report]

On 9 July 2020, a group of 5 military and police officers assaulted a doctor in Loeri Comba hospital of Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte), for refusing to give the priority to a young man that they were bringing to him, because of another emergency case he was treating.
Around 9 June 2020 (as reported), the military forces beat up one person in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte) while enforcing the counter coronavirus lockdown measure.
Around 9 June 2020 (as reported), five police officers violently beat up a woman in Bata town (Bata, Littoral) as they were enforcing the counter coronavirus lockdown measure.
On 31 March 2020, the government of Equatorial Guinea declared the state of health emergency for 30 days, to combat the coronavirus, and banned the gathering of more than 10 people.
On 24 March 2020, the government of Equatorial Guinea banned the gathering of more than 10 people to prevent the spread of coronavirus.
On 11 Feb. 2020, the security forces (assumed Police Forces) arrested the former president of the Supreme Court in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte). The reason of the arrest was unclear.
Police Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Prison Guards
Month of March. Police forces torture a Cameroon business person, Joseph Nseke, to death in Malabo of Bioko Norte over collusion with Maria Teresa Obiang, Francisco Massie or Juan Francisco.
27 February. A critical journalist, Paysa Elo Eyoto, is tortured in Malabo Detention Center of Bioko Norte by military forces.
CPDS: Convergence for Social Democracy Party
30 January. Protesters with the CPDS hang posters and demonstrate in Malabo against the presence of Yahya Jammeh in the country and demand his return to Gambia.
CEID: Center for Development Studies and Initiatives

27 October. Equatorial Guinea security forces take vice president of CEID, Alfredo Okenve, to a remote location and beat him at gunpoint before leaving the scene. He may have been mistaken for his brother, an opposition political figure.
Police Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Prison Guards
21 July. Jose Esono Ndong Bindang, a magistrate judge, is arrested on charges related to misappropriation of funds, but dies in prison due to lack of treatment for diabetes.
Police Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Prison Guards
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
On 2 July, an Equatorial Guinean opposition figure who had been jailed for 'sedition' was tortured to death in Evinayong Prison, according to his party, the Citizens for Innovation (CI).
Police Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Prison Guards
Former Military Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-); CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea

On 28 May, a former army captain and close relative of the Citizens for Innovation opposition party was reportedly murdered at the Malabo Central Prison. The leader claimed it was a state assassination. The ruling party deny the allegation.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
Non-violent activity: The main opposition party in Equatorial Guinea, Citizens for Innovation, was dissolved by a court. 21 CI activists were jailed for more than 30 years in the same court case.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
30 of the 150 activists on trial on Tuesday 13/2 had been tortured so badly that they could not stand up.
Security forces shot a mercenary in the Ebebeyin forest. They believe that he is part of a force that the government is accusing of attempting a coup.
Unidentified Armed Group (Chad); Unidentified Armed Group (Sudan); Unidentified Armed Group (Central African Republic)

Government troops clashed with militants on the Equatorial Guinea-Cameroon border. They accuse the militants of plotting a coup. The government claims that the militant group is made up mercenaries from Sudan, CAR and Chad. One militant was killed in the clash.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea

Police raided the opposition (CI) headquarters in Malabo. 200 opposition activists were arrested. Many of them were tortured. One opposition activist was tortured to death. The government claims he fell ill.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea
CI activists and police forces clashed in Aconibe during the election campaign. Several police officers were wounded and several activists were arrested.
On 18 Sept. 2017, a group of workers of the Androbras SL building company demonstrated in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte), to demand the payment of salary arrears. [size=no report]
On 20 July 2017, the military forces killed two people in Biyendem village, Bata subdivision (Bata, Littoral). The reasons of this remain unclear.

On 3 May 2017, the security forces (assumed Police Forces) reportedly engaged in violence and torture against several striking taxi drivers in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte), severely injured many taxi drivers. No demonstration activity was reported.
On 2 May 2017, security forces (assumed Police Forces) conducted a 'massive arrest' of taxi drivers in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte) following a general strike.
On 14 March 2017, a group of rioters beat up and injured a person that they caught stealing food in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte). [size=no report]
On 10 March 2017, a military officer shot and killed one person in Bata town (Bata, Littoral), following an argument on a unspecified issue.

On 10 March 2017, the police forces beat one young man to death in Malabo city (Malabo, Bioko Norte), after they stepped in to resolve an argument between the victim and his girlfriend in a night club.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea

Arrests: Between February and May, over 250 people were arrested for attending opposition party meetings in Eritrea in the context of the presidential election. All but four of those arrested were released without charge after being held for over a week. Members and sympathizers of the opposition party Citizens for Innovation (CI) were particularly targeted, as were relatives of the party Secretary-General, Gabriel Nze. Taxi drivers taking people to meetings were also arrested. In April, four days before the elections, some 140 people were arrested at Bata airport as they welcomed the CI Secretary-General. Others were arrested later in their homes.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea

On 22 April, police used excessive force against CI members who had gathered peacefully in the party's headquarters in Malabo. At about 4am, police in helicopters and armed vehicles surrounded the headquarters and used tear gas and live ammunition to force the approximately 200 party members out of the building. Four people were injured by bullets and taken to hospital over 24 hours later, following the intervention of the US Ambassador. At least 23 people were arrested and taken to Black Beach prison where they were beaten. All were released without charge on 30 April. The police siege of the CI's headquarters continued until 4 May.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea

Arrests: Police allegedly prevented opposition Citizens for Innovation (CI) party leader Gabriel Nse Obiang Obono and 200 of his supporters from leaving his residence in Malabo after an army assault on the property. As of 27 April, they were still under house arrest.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea

Soldiers and police launched an assault on opposition Citizens for Innovation (CI) party leader Gabriel Nse Obiang Obonos house in Malabo, using live ammunition against supporters of the party, allegedly injuring six severely.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea

Arrests: Between February and May, over 250 people were arrested for attending opposition party meetings in Eritrea in the context of the presidential election. All but four of those arrested were released without charge after being held for over a week. Members and sympathizers of the opposition party Citizens for Innovation (CI) were particularly targeted, as were relatives of the party Secretary-General, Gabriel Nze. Taxi drivers taking people to meetings were also arrested. In April, four days before the elections, some 140 people were arrested at Bata airport as they welcomed the CI Secretary-General. Others were arrested later in their homes.

Police arrested opposition party Union Centro Derecha campaign coordinator Rafael Mbela in Bata, while he was peacefully campaigning to promote his parties message. He was taken to a military base, where he was allegedly beaten and robbed.
CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea

Arrests: Between February and May, over 250 people were arrested for attending opposition party meetings in Eritrea in the context of the presidential election. All but four of those arrested were released without charge after being held for over a week. Taxi drivers taking people to meetings were also arrested. In April, four days before the elections, some 140 people were arrested at Bata airport as they welcomed the CI Secretary-General. CI: Citizens for the Innovation of Equatorial Guinea

Arrests: Between February and May, over 250 people were arrested for attending opposition party meetings in Eritrea in the context of the presidential election. All but four of those arrested were released without charge after being held for over a week. Members and sympathizers of the opposition party Citizens for Innovation (CI) were particularly targeted, as were relatives of the party Secretary-General, Gabriel Nze. Taxi drivers taking people to meetings were also arrested. In April, four days before the elections, some 140 people were arrested at Bata airport as they welcomed the CI Secretary-General. Others were arrested later in their homes.
Police officers in Equatorial Guinea on Saturday beat up a Nigerian diplomat, Noah Ichaba, on the street of Bata. He was later taken to a hospital where he was treated and discharged on the same day
On 24 July, around 50 students at the National University of Equatorial Guinea in Malabo protested against the non-payment of state stipends.
On 5 March, students at the National University of Equatorial Guinea in Malabo protested against the non-payment of state stipends. The protest is violently dispersed by police.

Police dispersed an opposition demonstration on Wednesday, arresting several organisers, who were protesting the authorities refusal to register a new political party in advance of upcoming elections.
Military Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Presidential Security Unit
Police forces shoot and kill a former army office and member of the presidential guard after he and 20 other escaped prison last week.
Mutiny of Military Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-)
Non-violent activity: Around 20 inmates, including army officers, broke free from Equatorial Guineas infamous Black Beach prison.
CPDS: Convergence for Social Democracy Party
Equatorial Guineas main opposition withdrew its agents from polling stations to protest against irregularities as the country voted in a referendum on a new constitution.

Seven foreigners were found killed in a rubbish yard. The deaths may have been motivated by politics - an exiled political party is investigating the matter and appealing to human rights organizations.
Non-violent activity: Obiang wins re-election with 95.5% of the vote. Many human rights organizations worldwide condemn the elections was crushing of human rights.
MEND: Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta
Suspected members of MEND attack the Presidential Palace. At least one attacker was shot and killed by palace security.
MEND: Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta
Equatorial Guinean troops and armed men who escaped security forces from the previous days attack on the presidential palace fought one another.
MEND: Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta
Military Forces of Equatorial Guinea (1979-) Presidential Security Unit
MEND: Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta

Armed men from Nigeria attacked the presidential palace. The armed men numbered between 15-20. Some of the Presidents guard shot at the armed men but it is unknown how many died on either side. At least one presidential guard died and two armed men.

Riots broke out while Chinese construction workers were protesting for better working conditions. The workers were part of a development project from China to help the infrastructure of Equatorial Guinea. Security forces intervened and killed two worker

Several opposition party members of the Progress Party of Equatorial Guinea (PPGE) have been detained and tortured by police in Eq. Guinea. Police detained PPGE members after they found weapons in their homes. One member died in custody after committin
Police raided and looted the homes of Cameroonians and intimidated Cameroonians in Bata in their search for two bank robbers.

Two banks were robbed by armed Cameroonians. The robbers stole cash and shot at civilians passing by. Police responded by raiding and looting the homes of Cameroonians in the city in their search for the robbers.
'A nun was attacked by an armed group of Cameroonians. As a result of the attack Equatorial Guinea decided to close the border at Kye-Ossie but keep the trading borders Douala and Campo open.'
PDGE: Equatorial Guinea Democratic Party (Equatorial Guinea)
Citizens of Equatorial Guinea, in a series of peaceful demonstrations marking the first anniversary of the failed 2004 coup, condemned terrorism and expressed support for the government
PDGE: Equatorial Guinea Democratic Party (Equatorial Guinea)
Citizens of Equatorial Guinea, in a series of peaceful demonstrations marking the first anniversary of the failed 2004 coup, condemned terrorism and expressed support for the government
An unidentified armed group from Cameroon attacked three stores in northern Equatorial Guinea.
A group of armed men attacked the Equatoguinean military barracks . Between 12 and 16 of the armed men were killed and five arrested. The five arrested are suspected to have been tortured.

Demonstrators marched in the streets of Malabo to show support for President Teodoro Obiang Nguema after a potential coup was discovered. Mercenaries flying from Zimbabwe to Equatorial Guinea were going to attempt a coup in Equatorial Guinea. The merce

A soldier shot dead a volunteer worker on a bus at the Mbon Ecua checkpoint. The event occurred when the bus driver drove on before given the final word to continue from the soldier. The soldier was angry and shot at the bus.
Opposition supporters were detained and tortured by security forces.
'Police were raping, beating and stealing money from sex workers in Malabo.'
'Cocoa farmers mainly from Bioko island staged a sit-in protest for payment on cocoa beans they produced.'
People of the Bubi ethnic group were tortured while in jail. People were in jail for the 1998 attacks on military barracks in Luba.

'Since the 21 January attack on Bioko Island which killed 5 soldiers over 100 people from the Bubi ethnic group were arrested detained and tortured. Fatalities: 6 civilians (as a result of torture and/or ill-treatment)'
'On the island of Bioko the port at Luba was attacked by an unidentified armed group suspected of being separatists for the region. Soldiers fought the group.'
PDGE: Equatorial Guinea Democratic Party (Equatorial Guinea)
CPDS: Convergence for Social Democracy Party; Women (Equatorial Guinea)
Six women members of the Convergence for Social Democracy (CDPS) were detained, stripped, and beaten, Amnesty reported
PDGE: Equatorial Guinea Democratic Party (Equatorial Guinea)
Two members of the illegal opposition party Fuerza Democrata Republicana (FDR), Republican Democratic Force, were arrested, severely beaten, and detained, Amnesty reports
PDGE: Equatorial Guinea Democratic Party (Equatorial Guinea)

Members of the opposition party Progress Party were arrested and tortured after the discovery of an alleged plot by PP leader to overthrow the government, at least two remained in detention in October, Amnesty reported
